citation.article-title: Thermotoga thermarum sp. nov. and Thermotoga neapolitana occuring in African continental solfataric springs.

p.s: Description of Thermotoga thermarum, Windberger, Huber and Stetter sp. nov.
Thermotoga thermarum (ther.ma'rum L. gen. n. thermarum, living in hot continental springs with low ionic strength)
Cells are Gram-negative rods, occurring singly and in pairs about 1.5 to 11 μm long and 0.6 μm in width, surrounded by a sheathlike outer structure, usually ballooning over the ends.
In the stationary growth phase the overballooning ends tend to become large spheres.
Yeast extract is required for growth.
Addition of starch, glucose and maltose stimulate growth.
Elemental sulfur is not reduced and prevents growth.
Cells do not grow in the presence of rifampicin (1 μg/ml).
Growth between 55 and 84 °C with an optimum at 70 °C (doubling time: 75 min), pH of growth between 6.0 and 9.0 with an optimum at around 7.
Growth between 0.2 and 0.55% NaCl with an optimum at around 0.35% NaCl.
The molecular weights of the RNA polymerase core enzyme subunits are 170,000, 135,000, 41,000.
Incomplete serological cross-reaction with Thermotoga maritima RNA polymerase antiserum.
The DNA base composition is about 40 mol% G+C.
No significant DNA homology with Thermotoga maritima and Thermotoga neapolitana.
Single strain isolated from a neutral hot water well with low salinity at Lac Abbé, Djibouti, Africa.
Type strain is Thermotoga thermarum, LA3, DSM 5069, Braunschweig, FRG.
